title: Sumaya Akter
text:
Hi!
I’m Sumaya Akter, a PhD student in Neuroscience (Biochemistry program) at the University of New Hampshire. I study how primary cilia and the Reelin signaling pathway** regulate neuronal migration and laminar organization in the cerebral cortex, with the long-term goal of connecting basic mechanisms to neurodevelopmental and cognitive disorders.
My work integrates confocal imaging, quantitative analysis, and rigorous statistics to map ciliary orientation, length, and apical localization across cortical regions.

title: About Me
text:
Hello! My name is Sumaya Akter, and I am a PhD student in Neuroscience at the University of New Hampshire.
My research focuses on how primary cilia signaling and the Reelin signaling pathway regulate neuronal migration and laminar organization in the cerebral cortex, with the long-term goal of linking these basic mechanisms to cognitive disorders.
I’m passionate about postnatal brain development, ciliary signaling, and cortical organization, integrating molecular biology and imaging techniques to explore brain structure and function.
Beyond the lab, I value scientific communication, data-driven neuroscience, and collaborative, open science.
